Option B. Its incidence has decreased after the introduction of vaccination: This statement is correct. The introduction of measles vaccination has significantly reduced the incidence of SSPE, as preventing the primary measles infection prevents the subsequent development of SSPE.

 

Option C. It most commonly affects individuals between 5 and 15 years old: This statement is correct. SSPE typically affects children and adolescents who had measles infection at a very young age, with disease onset usually occurring 6-8 years after the primary infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSPE presents with insidious behavioral and cognitive changes rather than acute symptoms like fever and headache, and represents a rare but devastating delayed complication of measles virus infection that has become increasingly uncommon due to vaccination.

choices.text: Nipah virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthrax

 

Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those deemed highest risk for use in bioterrorism due to their ease of dissemination or transmission and their high potential for significant public health impact, resulting in high mortality rates and the potential for major public health impact.

 

  • Characteristics of Anthrax:
    • Transmission: Can occur through cutaneous, inhalational, or gastrointestinal exposure to spore-forming bacteria.
    • Impact: Especially deadly in its inhalational form, anthrax can cause severe respiratory issues, shock, and often death if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah virus: It is not classified as a category A agent. It is a zoonotic virus that can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, primarily in Southeast Asia.

 

Option C. Coxiella: The bacterium that causes Q fever, is not classified as a category A agent. Q fever is typically acquired from infected animals or their products.

 

Option D. Brucella: It causes brucellosis, zoonotic infection primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Other category A agents are:

 

  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (Variola virus)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) - Francisella tularensis bacteria cause tularemia, also known as rabbit fever.

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and a fluctuating course, often varying in severity throughout the day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: This is more suggestive of dementia rather than delirium.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: The characteristic feature of delirium is a disturbance in consciousness and attention. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: While hallucinations can be present in delirium, they aren't specific to it. Schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders might also present with auditory hallucinations.

 

Therefore, a fluctuating course is the most suggestive of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is the most common organic mental disorder. It has an acute onset with a fluctuating course. It is most commonly seen in elderly population. It is characterized by disturbed consciousness, and altered attention. Disturbances of sleep-wake cycle, evening worsening of symptoms (sundowning), and floccillations can be seen.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook osf Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Which of the following regulates the body temperature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypothalamus

 

Explanation:


The regulation of body temperature is primarily controlled by the hypothalamus. Specifically, the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for cooling mechanisms, akin to standing in front of an air conditioner during hot weather. Conversely, the posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus manages warming mechanisms, similar to standing near an exhaust to receive warm air during cold weather.

This dual role in temperature regulation is unique to the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are involved in the coordination of movement and motor control, but they do not play a role in temperature regulation.

 

Option C. Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, and does not regulate body temperature.

 

Option D. Limbic system: The limbic system is involved in emotions, behavior, and long-term memory, but it does not have a role in the regulation of body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypothalamus, specifically its anterior and posterior nuclei, is responsible for regulating body temperature.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state.
  • TED may be associated with Graves’ disease, hypothyroidism, or euthyroidism, and the direct causative connection between thyroid dysfunction and ocular changes is unclear.
  • Main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma: Usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

 

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THYROID OPHTHALMOPATHY EYE SIGNS:

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

questions.text: A child was brought to ENT OPD with complaints of mouth breathing and snoring from a long duration. He also asks to increase the volume of TV while watching. What is the best treatment for this child’s condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy and grommet

 

The child presents with symptoms of mouth breathing and snoring, which are indicative of adenoid hypertrophy. The request to increase the TV volume suggests a hearing problem, likely due to conductive hearing loss caused by chronic adenoiditis with adenoid hypertrophy. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct the Eustachian tube, leading to fluid accumulation in the middle ear, known as otitis media with effusion. This condition causes conductive hearing loss.

 

Adenoidectomy involves the surgical removal of the adenoids to alleviate the obstruction. Inserting a grommet (tympanostomy tube) allows for drainage of the middle ear fluid, improving hearing and preventing recurrent otitis media.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy: While this addresses the adenoid hypertrophy, it does not address the fluid accumulation in the middle ear. The addition of a grommet is necessary for complete management.

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone would not resolve the underlying issue of adenoid hypertrophy and chronic Eustachian tube obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach would not be suitable given the chronic nature of the symptoms and the associated hearing loss. Delaying treatment could lead to further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of chronic adenoid hypertrophy causing mouth breathing, snoring, and conductive hearing loss, the best treatment involves adenoidectomy along with the insertion of a grommet to ensure proper drainage of middle ear fluid and restore normal hearing.

choices.text: It has one artery and two veins
It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the umbilical cord? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It has one artery and two veins

 

Explanation:

 

  • The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.
  • This 3 vessel umbilical cord appears as a “mickey-mouse sign” manner on the ultrasound finding
  • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and the 2 umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly: Wharton’s jelly is the gelatinous material surrounding the umbilical cord which protects it from external forces

 

Option C. Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies: A single umbilical artery is the most common anomaly in an umbilical cord.

 

It is associated with congenital anomalies such as genitourinary and cardiac anomalies

 

It may also be associated with Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome) and other chromosomal anomalies

 

Option D. Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm: The average length of the umbilical cord is 50 cm

 

Educational objective:

 

The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.

 

Ref: Page no 44, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A woman who got IUCD inserted at a PHC, now presents with bleeding. What should be done by the MO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron supplement and observation

 

Bleeding after IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) insertion is a common and typically normal physiological response. It is generally expected to subside within the first two menstrual cycles. While reassurance is important, simply reassuring the patient may not be sufficient, as persistent bleeding can lead to anemia.

 

The best approach is to supplement with iron (e.g., ferrous sulfate 200 mg TDS for 8 weeks) to prevent anemia while observing the patient. If the bleeding does not subside despite supplementation, the IUCD may need to be removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance: While reassurance is important, it alone may not be enough if the bleeding persists and leads to anemia.

 

Option B. Remove IUCD: Immediate removal of the IUCD is not the first line of management unless the bleeding persists despite supplementation and observation.

 

Option C. Antibiotics and IV fluids: These are not indicated unless there is an infection or severe bleeding, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron supplementation and observation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Support and education

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks.

 

The primary management for postpartum blues is support and education about the condition, emphasizing its transient nature and differentiating it from the more severe postpartum depression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Useful in postpartum depression but not needed for the milder blues.

 

Option B. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for postpartum depression but is not the primary treatment for transient postpartum blues.

 

Option C. Lithium carbonate: Not indicated for postpartum blues or depression; used mainly for bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is noted to have subcutaneous emphysema and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His vital signs are unstable. What is the immediate management for this patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

 

  • The clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side and unstable vitals suggests tension pneumothorax.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  •  This pressure can shift the mediastinum, compromise venous return to the heart, and result in hypotension or shock.
  • Immediate needle decompression or needle thoracostomy is necessary, which involves inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line to relieve the trapped air and stabilize the patient.
  • The definitive management is tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.
  • The clinical findings suggest a tension pneumothorax. An immediate decompression is needed to prevent circulatory collapse by allowing trapped air to escape, which can stabilize the patient until a chest tube can be placed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV fluids for resuscitation: While fluid resuscitation is vital in the management of trauma patients, the priority in this scenario, given the clinical findings suggestive of tension pneumothorax, is to relieve the trapped air. While IV fluids can support the circulatory system, they won't address the primary problem, which is the tension pneumothorax. The priority in trauma management follows the Airway -> Breathing -> Circulation (ABC) protocol.

 

Option C. Intubation and positive pressure ventilation: Intubation and positive pressure ventilation can be dangerous in a patient with tension pneumothorax. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the tension pneumothorax by forcing more air into the pleural space, which can lead to rapid cardiovascular collapse. Addressing the tension pneumothorax with needle decompression or chest tube insertion should be prioritized before considering intubation.

 

Option D. e-FAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma): While e-FAST is a valuable tool in the trauma setting to quickly evaluate for the presence of free fluid (e.g., blood) in the peritoneal, pericardial, or pleural spaces, it may not be the immediate choice when a patient presents with clear signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and is hemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention to relieve the tension is essential, and while ultrasound can confirm the presence of pneumothorax, in an unstable patient, clinical judgment and prompt action are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to follow-up after being treated for typhoid fever. His Laboratory findings reveal a Widal test with O antigen titer >1:20, H antigen titer >1:320, HA titer >1:20, and BH titer >1:20. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery

 

In the Widal test, the O antigen titer is expected to be >1:100 in acute infection, while the H antigen titer >1:200 suggests a recent or past infection. Here, the O antigen is low (1:20) while H antigen is high (1:320), indicating that the patient is in the recovery phase rather than acute infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute infection: Would show high O antigen titers as O antigen rises early in infection

 

Option B. Chronic infection: Both O and H titers would be low/flat

 

Option C. Past infection: Both O and H titers would be low/flat

 

Educational Objective:

 

In enteric fever recovery phase, O antigen titers fall while H antigen titers remain elevated before gradually declining.

questions.text: Infrapatellar bursitis is also known as? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Parson’s knee

 

Infrapatellar bursitis, also known as Parson's knee or Clergyman's knee, refers to the inflammation of the bursa located below the patella. This condition results from prolonged kneeling, which causes irritation and inflammation of the infrapatellar bursa. The term derives from the kneeling posture commonly adopted by clergymen during prayer, putting pressure on this specific bursa located beneath the patellar tendon at its attachment to the tibial tuberosity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Housemaid's knee - This is incorrect as Housemaid's knee specifically refers to prepatellar bursitis, which is inflammation of the bursa in front of the patella, not the infrapatellar bursa. This condition is named after housemaids who traditionally spent time kneeling while scrubbing floors.

 

 

Option C. Weaver's knee - This is incorrect as Weaver's bottom (not knee) refers to ischial bursitis. There is no recognized condition called "Weaver's knee" in orthopedic terminology.

 

Option D. Taylor's knee - This is incorrect. The term "Tailor's ankle" refers to lateral malleolus bursitis, but there is no established condition called "Taylor's knee" in orthopedic medicine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Infrapatellar bursitis is known as Parson's knee or Clergyman's knee, while prepatellar bursitis is termed Housemaid's knee - distinguishing between these conditions involves identifying the exact anatomical location of the inflamed bursa.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has experienced the loss of her newborn. She is currently producing breast milk, leading to discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent this complication? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the goal is to prevent lactation to avoid discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. The appropriate treatment involves using a drug that can suppress prolactin secretion, as prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion, effectively suppressing lactation. It is often used for this purpose and can be an effective choice in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an antiprogestin used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a direct role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that can increase prolactin levels, which would not be helpful in this context.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent and antiemetic that also increases prolactin levels, making it unsuitable for suppressing lactation.

 

Given these options, the correct choice for preventing lactation and thus avoiding the associated complications is: b. Cabergoline

questions.text: An immunoglobulin molecule is an example of which level of protein structure?      (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quaternary structure

 

Explanation:

 

Immunoglobulins are complex proteins composed of multiple polypeptide chains - specifically two identical heavy chains and two identical light chains. This arrangement of multiple polypeptides into a functional protein complex represents quaternary structure. Quaternary structure refers to the spatial arrangement between various types of polypeptides in protein. For immunoglobulins, scientists often use the designation α₂β₂ to indicate two heavy chains and two light chains forming the complete functional protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary structure: This refers only to the sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain. While each chain in an immunoglobulin has a primary structure, the complete immunoglobulin itself represents a higher level of organization.

 

Option B. Secondary structure: This refers to the folding of short (3-30 residue), contiguous segments of polypeptide into geometrically ordered units like α-helices and β-sheets. Immunoglobulins contain these elements, but as a complete protein they represent a higher level of structure.

 

Option C. Tertiary structure: This refers to the assembly of secondary structural units into larger functional units such as the mature polypeptide. Each individual chain of an immunoglobulin has tertiary structure, but the complete immunoglobulin with multiple chains represents quaternary structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunoglobulins exemplify quaternary protein structure as they consist of multiple polypeptide chains (two heavy and two light chains) assembled together to form a functional complex capable of recognizing and binding specific antigens.

questions.text: A malnourished child from a poor socioeconomic background, living in overcrowded and unsanitary conditions, presents with a nodule around the limbus and redness of the surrounding conjunctiva in his left eye. The child also has axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phlyctenular Conjunctivitis

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests phlyctenular conjunctivitis. This condition is characterized by a nodular lesion (phlycten) occurring at the limbus with surrounding hyperemia. It typically affects children living in poor hygienic conditions who are undernourished. The unilateral presentation is also characteristic, as phlyctenular conjunctivitis is usually unilateral, in contrast to conditions like vernal keratoconjunctivitis which are bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign Body Granuloma: This is incorrect because foreign body granulomas typically have a history of trauma or foreign body entry. They also don't correlate with the socioeconomic factors and malnutrition mentioned in the case. Foreign body granulomas are common following squint surgery or inadequately scraped chalazion.

 

Option C. Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis: This is incorrect because vernal keratoconjunctivitis is typically bilateral, seasonal (worse in warm weather), and characterized by severe itching, papillary hypertrophy arranged in a "cobblestone" pattern, and ropy discharge. It's not specifically associated with poor socioeconomic conditions or malnutrition.

 

Option D. Episcleritis: This is incorrect because episcleritis presents with sectoral redness without discharge, is more common in adults, and is not specifically associated with poor living conditions or malnutrition. The nodular lesion at the limbus is not a typical feature of episcleritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous microbial proteins, particularly common in malnourished children living in poor hygienic conditions, presenting as a characteristic whitish raised nodule on the bulbar conjunctiva with surrounding hyperemia

questions.text: High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA) is not caused by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diarrhea

 

Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA). There are only three main causes of NAGMA, remembered by the mnemonic "DRS":

 

  • D: Diarrhea
  • R: RTA (Renal Tubular Acidosis – types 1, 2, and 4)
  • S: Saline administration (causing hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): Incorrect. DKA is a classic cause of HAGMA. It leads to accumulation of ketone bodies, causing high anion gap.

 

Option C. Acute renal failure: Incorrect. Renal failure causes HAGMA due to accumulation of organic acids and decreased acid excretion.

 

Option D. Inborn errors of metabolism: Incorrect. Most inborn errors of metabolism cause HAGMA through accumulation of organic acids.

 

The causes of HAGMA can be remembered using the mnemonic "GOLDMARK":

 

  • G: Glycol (ethylene glycol)
  • O: Oxoproline (paracetamol metabolite)
  • L: L-lactate
  • D: D-lactate (short bowel syndrome)
  • M: Methanol
  • A: Aspirin
  • R: Renal failure
  • K: Ketoacidosis (diabetic, alcoholic, starvation)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA).

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents with severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. What is the Causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The clinical presentation of severe headache, high fever, papilloedema, and nuchal rigidity, combined with the Gram stain results, is highly indicative of meningococcal meningitis, caused by Neisseria meningitidis. The image from the Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing intracellular gram-negative diplococci supports this diagnosis. Neisseria meningitidis is known for appearing as gram-negative diplococci, often resembling kidney beans, and typically found within white blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

 

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus and typically presents with tumbling motility in liquid media, not as diplococci.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis - Intracellular gram-negative diplococci in gram staining.

questions.text: The treatment given to the patient presenting with a history of binge alcohol intake and symptoms of convulsions, altered sensorium, and plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiamine followed by dextrose


In patients with a history of chronic alcohol intake, thiamine deficiency is a common complication. Alcohol interferes with thiamine absorption and utilization, leading to deficiencies that can impact various metabolic processes, including carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine is a crucial cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA during glucose metabolism. Administering glucose without prior thiamine can precipitate acute thiamine deficiency symptoms, worsening the patient’s condition and potentially leading to Wernicke’s encephalopathy, a severe neurological disorder.

 

Therefore, in cases where hypoglycemia is present (as indicated by a plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL), the correct management is to first administer thiamine to replenish depleted stores and then follow with dextrose to correct the hypoglycemia safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25% dextrose: While dextrose is necessary to treat hypoglycemia, administering it before thiamine in a thiamine-deficient patient can worsen the deficiency, leading to serious neurological complications.

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This is used in the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not relevant in alcohol-induced hypoglycemia or thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine: While thiamine is part of the treatment, it alone does not correct hypoglycemia. Both thiamine and dextrose are necessary, in the correct order.

 

Educational Objective:


In alcohol-related hypoglycemia, always administer thiamine before dextrose to prevent the exacerbation of thiamine deficiency and associated complications.

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for patent ductus arteriosus, which structure in close relation to it can be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth, leaving an open connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. Surgical correction of this defect involves closing the ductus arteriosus.

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, loops under the arch of the aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum (the remnant of the ductus arteriosus). Due to its close proximity to the ductus arteriosus, this nerve is at risk of being damaged during surgical procedures aimed at correcting PDA. Injury to this nerve can result in hoarseness, voice changes, or even vocal cord paralysis due to its role in innervating the muscles of the larynx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagus nerve: While the vagus nerve is in the vicinity, it does not have the same close relationship with the ductus arteriosus as the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. The vagus nerve primarily runs along the side of the neck and thorax without looping directly near the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option C. Right recurrent laryngeal nerve: The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the right subclavian artery and does not pass near the ductus arteriosus, making it less likely to be damaged during surgery on the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option D. Phrenic nerve: The phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, runs more anteriorly in the thorax and does not have a close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus, thus it is not at significant risk during PDA surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is at significant risk of injury during surgical procedures for patent ductus arteriosus due to its close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause a pleural pathology? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin is an oral hypoglycemic agent used primarily in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and increasing insulin sensitivity. Metformin is not associated with pleural pathologies, making it the correct choice in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methysergide: Methysergide is a medication used to prevent migraine headaches and is known for its potential to cause retroperitoneal and pleural fibrosis. This pleural pathology is a serious adverse effect, although the drug is not commonly used today due to this risk.

 

Option C. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of various cancers. One of its well-known side effects is pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as pulmonary fibrosis. Pleural involvement, including pleural effusions and fibrosis, can occur secondary to its pulmonary effects.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic used primarily for urinary tract infections. It can cause pulmonary reactions, including acute, subacute, and chronic pulmonary reactions. These reactions can involve the pleura, leading to pleural effusions and other pleural pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is not associated with causing pleural pathologies, unlike Methysergide, Bleomycin, and Nitrofurantoin, which have known risks of causing pleural and pulmonary complications.

choices.text: Antibiotics are the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass.
Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection.
Crohn's disease most commonly involves the proximal ileum.
Continuous lesions observed during endoscopic examination are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of these is a true statement about Crohn’s disease?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection

 

Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection. The course of the disease after surgery is unpredictable since surgery does not cure Crohn's disease. The recurrence of Crohn's disease after surgery is common, and the likelihood of relapse may depend on the extent of disease involvement, the type of surgery performed, and other individual factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics are not the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass. Treatment options for Crohn's disease depend on the severity of the disease and may include anti-inflammatory drugs, immunosuppressants, and biologic agents, in addition to antibiotics.

 

Option C. The distal ileum is a common site of involvement in Crohn's disease, but the disease can affect any part of the digestive tract from the mouth to the anus. In addition to the ileum, other common sites of involvement include the colon, and perianal region.

 

Option D. The characteristic features of Crohn's disease on endoscopy include skip lesions, areas of inflammation, ulcers, and strictures, which may be continuous or segmental in nature.

 

Educational Objective:


Surgical resection in Crohn's disease does not cure the condition, and symptomatic relapse can occur independently of the presence of disease at the resection margins.

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

 

Explanation:

 

The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.

 

Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 162

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epinephrine

 

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

 

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are:

 

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

 

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon primarily works to increase blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It does not play a significant role in shifting potassium intracellularly.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks muscarinic receptors. It is not involved in potassium homeostasis or its intracellular movement.

 

Option D. Lactic acid: Lactic acid does not facilitate the intracellular movement of potassium. In fact, metabolic acidosis (which can be associated with elevated lactic acid levels) tends to cause potassium to move out of cells into the extracellular space, exacerbating hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 agonists, such as Epinephrine, are effective in promoting the intracellular movement of potassium, thereby reducing serum potassium levels in cases of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with celiac disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11

 

Celiac disease is associated with specific HLA types – DQ2 (present in 95% of cases) and DQ8. HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11 are not associated with celiac disease. The genetic predisposition to celiac disease is strongly linked to these specific HLA markers, which are essential for disease development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modified Marsh classification: Correct. Used for diagnosing celiac disease via endoscopic biopsies and to monitor improvement on a gluten-free diet.

 

Option B. IgA transglutaminase positivity: Correct. Anti-tissue transglutaminase IgA (anti-tTG IgA) is the most reliable serologic test.

 

Option C. IgG antigliadin positivity: Correct. Although less specific, it is useful especially in IgA-deficient patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is genetically associated with HLA-DQ2 (95% of cases) and HLA-DQ8, not HLA-DQ6 and HLA-DQ11.

questions.text: Pseudopolyps are typically seen in? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Ulcerative colitis

 

Explanation:

 

Pseudopolyps are a characteristic feature of ulcerative colitis, representing islands of regenerating mucosa that bulge into the lumen to create the appearance of polyps. They form as the mucosa attempts to heal after episodes of severe inflammation and ulceration. Pseudopolyps develop when isolated islands of regenerating mucosa often bulge into the lumen, and the tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges. These features are particularly common in chronic ulcerative colitis where repeated cycles of inflammation and healing have occurred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crohn's disease - While Crohn's disease can occasionally have pseudopolyps (described as "moderate" in comparison to ulcerative colitis where they are "marked"), they are much more characteristic of ulcerative colitis. Crohn's disease is typically characterized by transmural inflammation, skip lesions, granulomas, and fistulae formation rather than pseudopolyps.

 

Option C. Celiac disease - Celiac disease is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis in the small intestine. Pseudopolyps are not a feature of celiac disease.

 

Option D. Tropical sprue - Tropical sprue affects the small intestine with malabsorption as its primary manifestation. It involves total intestinal involvement but does not feature pseudopolyp formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pseudopolyps are characteristic of ulcerative colitis and represent islands of regenerating mucosa that project into the lumen, often forming after episodes of severe inflammation and ulceration; they can occasionally fuse at their tips to form mucosal bridges.

choices.text: It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh
A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication
Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy experienced symptoms of a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a slight fever. Upon examination, the presented clinical image is visible. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication

 

A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication: This is false. A prior adverse reaction with a temperature above 40 degrees Celsius is a contraindication, not 37 degrees Celsius. Minor reactions, such as a mild fever, are not typically considered a contraindication for future vaccinations.

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A.  It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh: This is true. The DPT vaccine is typically administered intramuscularly on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh in infants and young children.

 

Option C. Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age: This is true. The whole-cell pertussis vaccine is generally not recommended for individuals over the age of 7 due to an increased risk of adverse reactions. Instead, the acellular pertussis vaccine is used in older children and adults.

 

Option D. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose: This is true. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is lower than in pediatric formulations to reduce the risk of adverse reactions while still providing adequate immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fingerprint pattern

 

Monozygotic twins (Identical twins) are conceived when a single egg fertilized by a single sperm splits into two after fertilization. Such twins have 100% of their genes in common. Both of them invariably have the same blood type and are of the same sex.

 

 Dizygotic twins (Faternal twins) are conceived when two eggs are fertilized by two different sperms. They share 50% of their genes, just like any other siblings. Their blood types and sex can be either same or different.

 

So, all the inheritable characteristics will be exactly same in identical twins (e.g. Blood group, DNA fingerprinting, Iris Color).

 

But Fingerprints are not inheritable hence different even in identical twins. No finger-prints of 2 individuals are similar. It is 100% accurate method of identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood Group: Identical twins invariably have the same blood type.

 

Option B. DNA Fingerprinting: Identical twins have identical DNA profiles because they share the same genetic material.

 

Option D. Iris Color: Iris color, being a genetic trait, will be the same in identical twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While identical twins share the same blood group, DNA fingerprinting, and iris color due to their identical genetic makeup, their fingerprint patterns are unique to each individual due to non-inheritable factors.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presented with gum bleeding, easy bruising, and fatigue. He was suffering from fever for 1 month and on examination, he had pallor and a petechial rash distributed all over the body. His peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and his corrected reticulocyte count was 0.5%. Bone marrow revealed few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells. What should be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic Anemia

 

The patient's presentation of gum bleeding, easy bruising, fatigue, fever, pallor, and petechial rash suggests Pancytopenia. Pancytopenia can result from several conditions, but the key clues here are:

 

  • Bone marrow findings: The bone marrow shows few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells, indicating a hypocellular marrow.
  • Corrected reticulocyte count: A low corrected reticulocyte count (0.5%) indicates poor bone marrow response.

 

These findings are characteristic of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia, a condition where the bone marrow fails to produce adequate amounts of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated TB: Disseminated TB usually presents with systemic symptoms and may show a cellular bone marrow due to granulomas and other inflammatory changes, which is not consistent with the findings of a hypocellular marrow.

 

Option C. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH typically presents with hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and sometimes pancytopenia. However, it usually shows a cellular marrow unless it is associated with aplastic anemia. In exams, PNH is generally considered a cause of cellular marrow.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS usually presents with a hypercellular or normocellular marrow with dysplastic changes. It can cause pancytopenia, but the marrow is typically not hypocellular except in rare cases of hypoplastic MDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia should be considered in patients presenting with pancytopenia, bleeding, bruising, fatigue, and hypocellular bone marrow without significant inflammatory or immature cells. The diagnosis is supported by a low corrected reticulocyte count and clinical findings consistent with bone marrow failure.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior mesenteric vein

 

The structure shown by the arrow is SMV.

 

SMV is on the right, while SMA is on the left (Remember "SMAL").

 

They can be identified by the uncinate process at this level

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Superior Mesenteric Vein can be distinguished on a CT scan by its position to the right of the Superior Mesenteric Artery, and its relation to the uncinate process. Remembering "SMAL" (Superior Mesenteric Artery Left, Superior Mesenteric Vein Right) can aid in identification during diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

 

The umbilical arteries are responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the fetal heart to the placenta during gestation. In general, arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, but the pulmonary and umbilical arteries are unique in that they carry deoxygenated blood.

 

 

Clinical significance:

 

  1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery. The umbilical artery has the following fate:
    • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
  2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option C. Descending Aorta: In fetal circulation, the descending aorta distributes oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body and is not specifically involved in the transport of deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs in postnatal circulation but does not play a role in fetal circulation in terms of transport to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

 

FIBROUS DYSPLASIA

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly of bone formation.
  • The hallmark is replacement of normal bone and marrow by fibrous tissue and small woven spicules of bone.
  • Fibrous dysplasia can occur in the epiphysis, metaphysis, or diaphysis.
  • It may affect one bone (monostotic form) or several bones (polyostotic form).
  • The monostotic form is the most common and is usually diagnosed in patients between 20 and 30 years of age. It most commonly affects the femur.
  • The polyostotic form typically manifests in children <10 years of age and may progress with age. It most commonly affects the maxilla and other craniofacial bones.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome refers to polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cutaneous pigmentation (café au lait spots), and endocrine abnormalities (Precoceous puberty).
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” borders).
  • Fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur has shepherd crook deformity.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.

 

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity (looks like shepherds stick which is crooked in shape) bone is replaced by fibrous tissue in fibrous dysplasia.

  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim, called ‘Rind sign’.

     

 

A. Shepherd Crook deformity; B. Rind sign 

 

  • Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).
    • On biopsy, Chinese Letter Pattern is recognised.
    • Surgical treatment (Curettage + bone grafting) is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blade of grass deformity. The blade of grass sign, also called the candle flame sign, refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen during the lytic phase of Paget disease of bone. The lytic, or incipient active, phase of the disease is characterized by intense osteoclastic activity that is exhibited on radiographs as osteolysis. In the long bones, osteolysis is manifested as a characteristic metaphyseal to diaphyseal wedge-shaped area of radiolucency that assumes the configuration of a flame or blade of grass. This advancing wedge of osteolysis, which begins in the subchondral bone of the epiphysis and extends peripherally into the metaphysis and diaphysis, spreads about 1 cm per year and shows no marginal sclerosis. A potential pitfall is misdiagnosing the track sign of the femur as the blade of grass sign.

 

 

Option C. Chicken wire appearance. Histopathologically, cellular areas in chondroblastoma are composed of “chondroblasts” with an oval to round nucleus and with well-defined eosinophilic cytoplasm. A fine network of pericellular calcification called “chicken wire calcification” are seen in the cytoplasm or stroma some cases.

 

 

Option D. Corduroy appearance. Hemangioma is a common benign bone lesion. It is estimated that 10% of the population has asymptomatic hemangioma of the vertebral bodies. Hemangiomas also are common in the skull. They usually are discovered as incidental findings. The radiographic appearance in the spine usually is characteristic, with thickened, vertically oriented trabeculae giving the classic “jailhouse” (Corduroy) appearance. In cross-section, these thickened trabeculae have a “polka dot” pattern on CT scan.

 

Treatment usually is not necessary.

 

 

Polka dot appearance on CT scan

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with severe abdominal distension, pain, and absolute constipation for the past two days. Physical examination reveals a distended, tympanic abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sigmoid volvulus

 

Explanation: 


The case presents classical features of sigmoid volvulus, which is confirmed by the radiological findings showing:

 

  • Classic "coffee bean" sign - two dilated bowel loops without haustra
  • Common in elderly patients
  • Presents with severe abdominal distension and constipation The diagnosis is supported by typical patient demographics (elderly) and clinical presentation (constipation, distension). Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus, particularly in older patients with chronic constipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small bowel volvulus: Shows different radiological pattern with "step ladder" appearance of dilated small bowel loops. Small bowel shows complete mucosal folds (valvulae connivence’s), unlike the pattern seen here.

 

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: While present here, this is a general term. The specific type (sigmoid volvulus) can be identified by the characteristic radiological appearance. Small bowel obstruction shows complete mucosal folds, while large bowel obstruction shows haustra.

 

Option D. Caecal volvulus: Shows a single dilated loop with haustral pattern forming a "C" sign, unlike the double-loop "coffee bean" appearance seen in sigmoid volvulus. Cecal volvulus is less common than sigmoid volvulus.

 

 

Educational Objective: 


Sigmoid volvulus presents with the characteristic "coffee bean" sign on X-ray (two dilated loops without haustra) and typically occurs in elderly patients with chronic constipation.



Sigmoid Volvulus vs Cecal Volvulus

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below which is characterized by development of morphologically similar lesions along the lines of trauma:  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isomorphic phenomenon

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

 

Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon:

 

Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Gottron's papule seen associated with Dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign

 

Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D: Meyerson phenomenon is a melanocytic nevus that has developed an eczematous ring around it as seen in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isomorphic phenomenon (Koebner phenomenon) as the appearance of skin lesions similar to a primary disease along areas of skin trauma, which is important for diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 123.2

questions.text: What is the recommended BMI cut-off for the 'Normal' category among the Indian population? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 23

 

  • The normal BMI range for the Indian population is defined as 18.5 to 22.99. Once a person reaches a BMI of 23, they move into the overweight/pre-obese category by Indian standards. 
  • This lower cut-off point reflects the specific body composition patterns observed in South Asian populations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 35: This value is significantly higher than the Indian cut-off for normal BMI. A BMI of 35 represents severe obesity (Class II obesity) and is associated with substantially increased health risks.

 

Option B. 30: This represents the threshold for obesity in global classifications. For Indian populations, this value is well above both the normal range and even the overweight category.

 

Option C. 25: While this is used as the upper limit of normal BMI in some classifications, for Indian populations, a BMI of 25 or above already falls into the obesity category, not the normal range.

 

Significance of Different BMI Classifications:

 

Indian BMI classifications use lower cut-off points because South Asian populations typically develop metabolic complications at lower BMI levels than Western populations. South Asians tend to have higher body fat percentages and central adiposity at the same BMI compared to Caucasians.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Indian populations, the normal BMI range is 18.5-22.99, with 23 being the cut-off point above which a person is classified as overweight.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness, anemia, bony pain & hepatosplenomegaly. A histological picture is shown with cells in bone marrow. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluco-Cerebrosidase

 

The picture show macrophages with typical crumpled tissue paper appearance/ wrinkled appearance that is highly characteristic of Gaucher’s disease (most common lysosomal storage disease). Glucocerebrosides accumulate in reticuloendothelial system due to deficiency of enzyme β-Glucocerebrosidase. These patients have bony pain, pathological fractures, hepatosplenomegaly, but no mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Deficiency of Glucose 6 phosphatase is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD-I) or von Gierke disease. This disorder primarily affects glucose metabolism and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase A: Hexosaminidase A deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, which primarily affects the nervous system and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option D. Beta-Galactosidase: Deficiency of Beta-Galactosidase is associated with GM1 gangliosidosis. This lysosomal storage disorder primarily affects the nervous system and is not typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluco-Cerebrosidase, is associated with Gaucher's disease, a rare inherited metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucosylceramide due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. Gaucher's disease can lead to the symptoms described, including hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and bony pain.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 235

questions.text: Recommended sequence of premedication during elective intubation in a neonate is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine > Fentanyl > Vecuronium

 

In neonatal intubation, the correct sequence starts with atropine to prevent bradycardia, which is especially important in neonates who are particularly sensitive to vagal stimulation during laryngoscopy. Bradycardia is the most common adverse cardiac event during the perioperative period in pediatric patients. Following atropine, fentanyl (a short-acting opioid) provides analgesia and some sedation, and finally vecuronium (a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant) facilitates intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal intubation, always administer atropine first to prevent bradycardia, followed by analgesic medication (fentanyl), and only then a muscle relaxant (vecuronium) - this sequence protects cardiovascular stability while ensuring adequate analgesia before paralysis.

choices.text: Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Spinal Cord

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy arrives at the outpatient clinic with a history of progressively worsening difficulty in walking and frequent episodes of falling. Physical examination shows an ataxic gait with absent deep tendon reflexes. The Babinski sign is negative, and the plantar reflex demonstrates an extensor response. Which diagnosis is most likely? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Friedreich's Ataxia

 

Friedreich's ataxia is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia, absent deep tendon reflexes, and pyramidal signs. The clinical presentation of a 12-year-old boy with progressively worsening gait difficulty, ataxia, and absent deep tendon reflexes strongly suggests this diagnosis. Friedreich's ataxia typically presents in childhood or adolescence (before age 25) and affects the posterior columns, spinocerebellar tracts, and corticospinal tracts, leading to the combination of sensory ataxia and pyramidal signs. The loss of deep tendon reflexes reflects peripheral sensory neuronopathy, while extensor plantar responses indicate corticospinal tract involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option Subacute Combined Degeneration: While this also affects posterior columns and corticospinal tracts, it's caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and typically presents in adults. It would show increased, not absent, deep tendon reflexes.

 

Option Becker's Muscular Dystrophy: This dystrophinopathy presents with proximal muscle weakness rather than ataxia. Reflexes would be preserved until late in the disease, and there would be no sensory involvement or extensor plantar responses.

 

Option Tabes Dorsalis: This manifestation of tertiary syphilis is extremely rare in children. While it causes sensory ataxia and areflexia, it lacks pyramidal signs (would not have extensor plantar responses) and would be highly unusual in a 12-year-old.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of progressive ataxia, absent deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar responses in an adolescent is the classic presentation of Friedreich's ataxia, reflecting the disease's characteristic involvement of multiple spinal cord pathways.
